member.name: T:Godot.ARVRAnchor
member.summary: The ARVR Anchor point is a spatial node that maps a real world location identified by the AR platform to a position within the game world. For example, as long as plane detection in ARKit is on, ARKit will identify and update the position of planes (tables, floors, etc) and create anchors for them. This node is mapped to one of the anchors through its unique id. When you receive a signal that a new anchor is available, you should add this node to your scene for that anchor. You can predefine nodes and set the id and the nodes will simply remain on 0,0,0 until a plane is recognised. Keep in mind that, as long as plane detection is enabled, the size, placing and orientation of an anchor will be updated as the detection logic learns more about the real world out there especially if only part of the surface is in view.

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRAnchor.AnchorId
member.summary: The anchor's id. You can set this before the anchor itself exists. The first anchor gets an id of [code]1[/code], the second an id of [code]2[/code], etc. When anchors get removed, the engine can then assign the corresponding id to new anchors. The most common situation where anchors 'disappear' is when the AR server identifies that two anchors represent different parts of the same plane and merges them.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRAnchor.GetAnchorName
member.summary: Returns the name given to this anchor.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRAnchor.GetIsActive
member.summary: Returns true if the anchor is being tracked and false if no anchor with this id is currently known.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRAnchor.GetSize
member.summary: Returns the estimated size of the plane that was detected. Say when the anchor relates to a table in the real world, this is the estimated size of the surface of that table.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRAnchor.GetPlane
member.summary: Returns a plane aligned with our anchor; handy for intersection testing.

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRCamera
member.summary: This is a helper spatial node for our camera; note that, if stereoscopic rendering is applicable (VR-HMD), most of the camera properties are ignored, as the HMD information overrides them. The only properties that can be trusted are the near and far planes. The position and orientation of this node is automatically updated by the ARVR Server to represent the location of the HMD if such tracking is available and can thus be used by game logic. Note that, in contrast to the ARVR Controller, the render thread has access to the most up-to-date tracking data of the HMD and the location of the ARVRCamera can lag a few milliseconds behind what is used for rendering as a result.

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRController
member.summary: This is a helper spatial node that is linked to the tracking of controllers. It also offers several handy passthroughs to the state of buttons and such on the controllers. Controllers are linked by their id. You can create controller nodes before the controllers are available. Say your game always uses two controllers (one for each hand) you can predefine the controllers with id 1 and 2 and they will become active as soon as the controllers are identified. If you expect additional controllers to be used, you should react to the signals and add ARVRController nodes to your scene. The position of the controller node is automatically updated by the ARVR Server. This makes this node ideal to add child nodes to visualise the controller.

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRController.ControllerId
member.summary: The controller's id. A controller id of 0 is unbound and will always result in an inactive node. Controller id 1 is reserved for the first controller that identifies itself as the left hand controller and id 2 is reserved for the first controller that identifies itself as the right hand controller. For any other controller that the [ARVRServer] detects, we continue with controller id 3. When a controller is turned off, its slot is freed. This ensures controllers will keep the same id even when controllers with lower ids are turned off.

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRController.Rumble
member.summary: The degree to which the tracker rumbles. Ranges from [code]0.0[/code] to [code]1.0[/code] with precision [code].01[/code]. If changed, updates [member ARVRPositionalTracker.rumble] accordingly.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetControllerName
member.summary: If active, returns the name of the associated controller if provided by the AR/VR SDK used.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetJoystickId
member.summary: Returns the ID of the joystick object bound to this. Every controller tracked by the ARVR Server that has buttons and axis will also be registered as a joystick within Godot. This means that all the normal joystick tracking and input mapping will work for buttons and axis found on the AR/VR controllers. This ID is purely offered as information so you can link up the controller with its joystick entry.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.IsButtonPressed(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns [code]true[/code] if the button at index [code]button[/code] is pressed.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetJoystickAxis(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the value of the given axis for things like triggers, touchpads, etc. that are embedded into the controller.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetIsActive
member.summary: Returns [code]true[/code] if the bound controller is active. ARVR systems attempt to track active controllers.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetHand
member.summary: Returns the hand holding this controller, if known. See TRACKER_* constants in [ARVRPositionalTracker].

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRInterface
member.summary: This class needs to be implemented to make an AR or VR platform available to Godot and these should be implemented as C++ modules or GDNative modules (note that for GDNative the subclass ARVRScriptInterface should be used). Part of the interface is exposed to GDScript so you can detect, enable and configure an AR or VR platform. Interfaces should be written in such a way that simply enabling them will give us a working setup. You can query the available interfaces through ARVRServer.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Tracking_status.NormalTracking
member.summary: Tracking is behaving as expected.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Tracking_status.ExcessiveMotion
member.summary: Tracking is hindered by excessive motion, player is moving faster then tracking can keep up.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Tracking_status.InsufficientFeatures
member.summary: Tracking is hindered by insufficient features, it's too dark (for camera based tracking), player is blocked, etc.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Tracking_status.UnknownTracking
member.summary: We don't know the status of the tracking or this interface does not provide feedback.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Tracking_status.NotTracking
member.summary: Tracking is not functional (camera not plugged in or obscured, lighthouses turned off, etc.)

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Eyes.Mono
member.summary: Mono output, this is mostly used internally when retrieving positioning information for our camera node or when stereo scopic rendering is not supported.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Eyes.Left
member.summary: Left eye output, this is mostly used internally when rendering the image for the left eye and obtaining positioning and projection information.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Eyes.Right
member.summary: Right eye output, this is mostly used internally when rendering the image for the right eye and obtaining positioning and projection information.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Capabilities.None
member.summary: No ARVR capabilities.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Capabilities.Mono
member.summary: This interface can work with normal rendering output (non-HMD based AR).

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Capabilities.Stereo
member.summary: This interface supports stereoscopic rendering.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Capabilities.Ar
member.summary: This interface support AR (video background and real world tracking).

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.Capabilities.External
member.summary: This interface outputs to an external device, if the main viewport is used the on screen output is an unmodified buffer of either the left or right eye (stretched if the viewport size is not changed to the same aspect ratio of get_render_targetsize. Using a separate viewport node frees up the main viewport for other purposes.

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRInterface.InterfaceIsPrimary
member.summary: Is this our primary interface?

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRInterface.InterfaceIsInitialized
member.summary: Has this interface been initialized?

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRInterface.ArIsAnchorDetectionEnabled
member.summary: On an AR interface, is our anchor detection enabled?

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.GetName
member.summary: Returns the name of this interface (OpenVR, OpenHMD, ARKit, etc).

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.GetCapabilities
member.summary: Returns a combination of flags providing information about the capabilities of this interface.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.Initialize
member.summary: Call this to initialize this interface. The first interface that is initialized is identified as the primary interface and it will be used for rendering output. After initializing the interface you want to use you then need to enable the AR/VR mode of a viewport and rendering should commence. Note that you must enable the AR/VR mode on the main viewport for any device that uses the main output of Godot such as for mobile VR. If you do this for a platform that handles its own output (such as OpenVR) Godot will show just one eye without distortion on screen. Alternatively you can add a separate viewport node to your scene and enable AR/VR on that viewport and it will be used to output to the HMD leaving you free to do anything you like in the main window such as using a separate camera as a spectator camera or render out something completely different. While currently not used you can activate additional interfaces, you may wish to do this if you want to track controllers from other platforms. However at this point in time only one interface can render to an HMD.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.Uninitialize
member.summary: Turns the interface off.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.GetTrackingStatus
member.summary: If supported, returns the status of our tracking. This will allow you to provide feedback to the user whether there are issues with positional tracking.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.GetRenderTargetsize
member.summary: Returns the resolution at which we should render our intermediate results before things like lens distortion are applied by the VR platform.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.IsStereo
member.summary: Returns true if the current output of this interface is in stereo.

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRInterfaceGDNative
member.summary: This is a wrapper class for GDNative implementations of the ARVR interface. To use a GDNative ARVR interface simply instantiate this object and set your GDNative library containing the ARVR interface implementation.

member.name: T:Godot.ARVROrigin
member.summary: This is a special node within the AR/VR system that maps the physical location of the center of our tracking space to the virtual location within our game world. There should be only one of these nodes in your scene and you must have one. All the ARVRCamera, ARVRController and ARVRAnchor nodes should be direct children of this node for spatial tracking to work correctly. It is the position of this node that you update when your character needs to move through your game world while we're not moving in the real world. Movement in the real world is always in relation to this origin point. So say that your character is driving a car, the ARVROrigin node should be a child node of this car. If you implement a teleport system to move your character, you change the position of this node. Etc.

member.name: P:Godot.ARVROrigin.WorldScale
member.summary: Allows you to adjust the scale to your game's units. Most AR/VR platforms assume a scale of 1 game world unit = 1 meter in the real world. Note that this method is a passthrough to the [ARVRServer] itself.

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker
member.summary: An instance of this object represents a device that is tracked such as a controller or anchor point. HMDs aren't represented here as they are fully handled internally. As controllers are turned on and the AR/VR interface detects them instances of this object are automatically added to this list of active tracking objects accessible through the ARVRServer The ARVRController and ARVRAnchor both consume objects of this type and should be the objects you use in game. The positional trackers are just the under the hood objects that make this all work and are mostly exposed so GDNative based interfaces can interact with them.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.TrackerHand.HandUnknown
member.summary: The hand this tracker is held in is unknown or not applicable.

member.summary: This tracker is the left hand controller.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.TrackerHand.RightHand
member.summary: This tracker is the right hand controller.

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.Rumble

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.GetType
member.summary: Returns the tracker's type.

member.summary: Returns the controller or anchor point's name if available.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.GetJoyId

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRServer
member.summary: The AR/VR Server is the heart of our AR/VR solution and handles all the processing.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRServer.RotationMode.ResetFullRotation
member.summary: Fully reset the orientation of the HMD. Regardless of what direction the user is looking to in the real world. The user will look dead ahead in the virtual world.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRServer.RotationMode.ResetButKeepTilt
member.summary: Resets the orientation but keeps the tilt of the device. So if we're looking down, we keep looking down but heading will be reset.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRServer.RotationMode.DontResetRotation
member.summary: Does not reset the orientation of the HMD, only the position of the player gets centered.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRServer.TrackerType.Controller
member.summary: Our tracker tracks the location of a controller.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRServer.TrackerType.Basestation
member.summary: Our tracker tracks the location of a base station.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRServer.TrackerType.Anchor
member.summary: Our tracker tracks the location and size of an AR anchor.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRServer.TrackerType.AnyKnown
member.summary: Used internally to filter trackers of any known type.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRServer.TrackerType.Unknown
member.summary: Used internally if we haven't set the tracker type yet.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRServer.TrackerType.Any
member.summary: Used internally to select all trackers.

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRServer.WorldScale
member.summary: Allows you to adjust the scale to your game's units. Most AR/VR platforms assume a scale of 1 game world unit = 1 meter in the real world.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRServer.GetReferenceFrame
member.summary: Gets our reference frame transform, mostly used internally and exposed for GDNative build interfaces.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRServer.CenterOnHmd(Godot.ARVRServer.RotationMode,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This is a really important function to understand correctly. AR and VR platforms all handle positioning slightly differently. For platforms that do not offer spatial tracking our origin point (0,0,0) is the location of our HMD but you have little control over the direction the player is facing in the real world. For platforms that do offer spatial tracking our origin point depends very much on the system. For OpenVR our origin point is usually the center of the tracking space, on the ground. For other platforms its often the location of the tracking camera. This method allows you to center our tracker on the location of the HMD, it will take the current location of the HMD and use that to adjust all our tracking data in essence realigning the real world to your players current position in your game world. For this method to produce usable results tracking information should be available and this often takes a few frames after starting your game. You should call this method after a few seconds have passed, when the user requests a realignment of the display holding a designated button on a controller for a short period of time, and when implementing a teleport mechanism.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRServer.GetHmdTransform
member.summary: Returns the primary interface's transformation.

If your game supports multiple AR/VR platforms, you can look through the available interface, and either present the user with a selection or simply try an initialize each interface and use the first one that returns true.

member.name: T:Godot.AStar
member.summary: A* (A star) is a computer algorithm that is widely used in pathfinding and graph traversal, the process of plotting an efficiently directed path between multiple points. It enjoys widespread use due to its performance and accuracy. Godot's A* implementation make use of vectors as points. You must add points manually with [method AStar.add_point] and create segments manually with [method AStar.connect_points]. So you can test if there is a path between two points with the [method AStar.are_points_connected] function, get the list of existing ids in the found path with [method AStar.get_id_path], or the points list with [method AStar.get_point_path].

member.name: M:Godot.AStar._ComputeCost(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Called when computing the cost between two connected points.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar._EstimateCost(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Called when estimating the cost between a point and the path's ending point.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetAvailablePointId
member.summary: Returns the next available point id with no point associated to it.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.AddPoint(System.Int32,Godot.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Adds a new point at the given position with the given identifier. The algorithm prefers points with lower [code]weight_scale[/code] to form a path. The [code]id[/code] must be 0 or larger, and the [code]weight_scale[/code] must be 1 or larger. [codeblock] var as = AStar.new() as.add_point(1, Vector3(1, 0, 0), 4) # Adds the point (1, 0, 0) with weight_scale 4 and id 1 [/codeblock] If there already exists a point for the given id, its position and weight scale are updated to the given values.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetPointPosition(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the position of the point associated with the given id.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.SetPointPosition(System.Int32,Godot.Vector3)
member.summary: Sets the position for the point with the given id.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetPointWeightScale(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the weight scale of the point associated with the given id.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.SetPointWeightScale(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the [code]weight_scale[/code] for the point with the given id.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.RemovePoint(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the point associated with the given id from the points pool.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.HasPoint(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns whether a point associated with the given id exists.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetPoints
member.summary: Returns an array of all points.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetPointConnections(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns an array with the ids of the points that form the connect with the given point. [codeblock] var as = AStar.new() as.add_point(1, Vector3(0, 0, 0)) as.add_point(2, Vector3(0, 1, 0)) as.add_point(3, Vector3(1, 1, 0)) as.add_point(4, Vector3(2, 0, 0)) as.connect_points(1, 2, true) as.connect_points(1, 3, true) var neighbors = as.get_point_connections(1) # returns [2, 3] [/codeblock]

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.ConnectPoints(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a segment between the given points. If [code]bidirectional[/code] is [code]false[/code], only movement from [code]id[/code] to [code]to_id[/code] is allowed, not the reverse direction. [codeblock] var as = AStar.new() as.add_point(1, Vector3(1, 1, 0)) as.add_point(2, Vector3(0, 5, 0)) as.connect_points(1, 2, false) [/codeblock]

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.DisconnectPoints(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Deletes the segment between the given points.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.ArePointsConnected(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns whether there is a connection/segment between the given points.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.Clear
member.summary: Clears all the points and segments.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetClosestPoint(Godot.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns the id of the closest point to [code]to_position[/code]. Returns -1 if there are no points in the points pool.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetClosestPositionInSegment(Godot.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns the closest position to [code]to_position[/code] that resides inside a segment between two connected points. [codeblock] var as = AStar.new() as.add_point(1, Vector3(0, 0, 0)) as.add_point(2, Vector3(0, 5, 0)) as.connect_points(1, 2) var res = as.get_closest_position_in_segment(Vector3(3, 3, 0)) # returns (0, 3, 0) [/codeblock] The result is in the segment that goes from [code]y = 0[/code] to [code]y = 5[/code]. It's the closest position in the segment to the given point.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetPointPath(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns an array with the points that are in the path found by AStar between the given points. The array is ordered from the starting point to the ending point of the path.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetIdPath(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns an array with the ids of the points that form the path found by AStar between the given points. The array is ordered from the starting point to the ending point of the path. [codeblock] var as = AStar.new() as.add_point(1, Vector3(0, 0, 0)) as.add_point(2, Vector3(0, 1, 0), 1) # default weight is 1 as.add_point(3, Vector3(1, 1, 0)) as.add_point(4, Vector3(2, 0, 0)) as.connect_points(1, 2, false) as.connect_points(2, 3, false) as.connect_points(4, 3, false) as.connect_points(1, 4, false) as.connect_points(5, 4, false) var res = as.get_id_path(1, 3) # returns [1, 2, 3] [/codeblock] If you change the 2nd point's weight to 3, then the result will be [code][1, 4, 3][/code] instead, because now even though the distance is longer, it's "easier" to get through point 4 than through point 2.

member.name: P:Godot.AtlasTexture.FilterClip

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor
member.summary: Dynamic range compressor reduces the level of the sound when the amplitude goes over a certain threshold in Decibels. One of the main uses of a compressor is to increase the dynamic range by clipping as little as possible (when sound goes over 0dB). Compressor has many uses in the mix: - In the Master bus to compress the whole output (Although a [AudioEffectLimiter] is probably better) - In voice channels to ensure they sound as balanced as possible. - Sidechained. Sidechained, which can reduce the sound level sidechained with another audio bus for threshold detection.. This technique is very common in video game mixing to download the level of Music/SFX while voices are being heard. - Accentuates transients by using a wider attack, making effects sound more punchy.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.Threshold
member.summary: The level above which compression is applied to the audio. Value can range from -60 to 0. Default value: [code]0[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.Ratio
member.summary: Amount of compression applied to the audio once it passes the threshold level. The higher the ratio the more the loud parts of the audio will be compressed. Value can range from 1 to 48. Default value: [code]4[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.Gain
member.summary: Gain applied to the output signal.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.AttackUs
member.summary: Compressor's reaction time when the signal exceeds the threshold. Value can range from 20 to 2000. Default value: [code]20ms[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.ReleaseMs
member.summary: Compressor's delay time to stop reducing the signal after the signal level falls below the threshold. Value can range from 20 to 2000. Default value: [code]250ms[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.Mix
member.summary: Balance between original signal and effect signal. Value can range from 0 (totally dry) to 1 (totally wet). Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.Sidechain
member.summary: Reduce the sound level using another audio bus for threshold detection.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectDelay
member.summary: Plays input signal back after a period of time. The delayed signal may be played back multiple times to create the sound of a repeating, decaying echo. Delay effects range from a subtle echo effect to a pronounced blending of previous sounds with new sounds.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Dry
member.summary: Output percent of original sound. At 0, only delayed sounds are output. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap1__active
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], [code]tap1[/code] will be enabled. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap1__delayMs
member.summary: [b]Tap1[/b] delay time in milliseconds. Default value: [code]250ms[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap1__levelDb
member.summary: Sound level for [code]tap1[/code]. Default value: [code]-6 dB[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap1__pan
member.summary: Pan position for [code]tap1[/code]. Value can range from -1 (fully left) to 1 (fully right). Default value: [code]0.2[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap2__active
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], [code]tap2[/code] will be enabled. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap2__delayMs
member.summary: [b]Tap2[/b] delay time in milliseconds. Default value: [code]500ms[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap2__levelDb
member.summary: Sound level for [code]tap2[/code]. Default value: [code]-12 dB[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap2__pan
member.summary: Pan position for [code]tap2[/code]. Value can range from -1 (fully left) to 1 (fully right). Default value: [code]-0.4[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Feedback__active
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], feedback is enabled. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Feedback__delayMs
member.summary: Feedback delay time in milliseconds. Default value: [code]340[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Feedback__levelDb
member.summary: Sound level for [code]tap1[/code]. Default value: [code]-6 dB[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Feedback__lowpass
member.summary: Low-pass filter for feedback. Frequencies below the Low Cut value are filtered out of the source signal. Default value: [code]16000[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion
member.summary: Modify the sound and make it dirty. Different types are available : clip, tan, lofi (bit crushing), overdrive, or waveshape. By distorting the waveform the frequency content change, which will often make the sound "crunchy" or "abrasive". For games, it can simulate sound coming from some saturated device or speaker very efficiently.

member.name: F:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.ModeEnum.Clip
member.summary: Digital distortion effect which cuts off peaks at the top and bottom of the waveform.

member.name: F:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.ModeEnum.Lofi
member.summary: Low-resolution digital distortion effect. You can use it to emulate the sound of early digital audio devices.

member.name: F:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.ModeEnum.Overdrive
member.summary: Emulates the warm distortion produced by a field effect transistor, which is commonly used in solid-state musical instrument amplifiers.

member.name: F:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.ModeEnum.Waveshape
member.summary: Waveshaper distortions are used mainly by electronic musicians to achieve an extra-abrasive sound.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.Mode
member.summary: Distortion type. Default value: [code]MODE_CLIP[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.PreGain
member.summary: Increases or decreases the volume before the effect. Value can range from -60 to 60. Default value: [code]0[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.KeepHfHz
member.summary: High-pass filter. Frequencies higher than this value will not be affected by the distortion. Value can range from 1 to 20000. Default value: [code]16000[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.Drive
member.summary: Distortion power. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]0[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.PostGain
member.summary: Increases or decreases the volume after the effect. Value can range from -80 to 24. Default value: [code]0[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectEQ
member.summary: AudioEffectEQ gives you control over frequencies. Use it to compensate for existing deficiencies in audio. AudioEffectEQ are very useful on the Master Bus to completely master a mix and give it character. They are also very useful when a game is run on a mobile device, to adjust the mix to that kind of speakers (it can be added but disabled when headphones are plugged).

member.name: M:Godot.AudioEffectEQ.SetBandGainDb(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets band's gain at the specified index, in dB.

member.name: M:Godot.AudioEffectEQ.GetBandGainDb(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the band's gain at the specified index, in dB.

member.name: M:Godot.AudioEffectEQ.GetBandCount
member.summary: Returns the number of bands of the equalizer.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectEQ10
member.summary: Frequency bands : Band 1 : 31 Hz Band 2 : 62 Hz Band 3 : 125 Hz Band 4 : 250 Hz Band 5 : 500 Hz Band 6 : 1000 Hz Band 7 : 2000 Hz Band 8 : 4000 Hz Band 9 : 8000 Hz Band 10 : 16000 Hz See also [AudioEffectEQ], [AudioEffectEQ6], [AudioEffectEQ21].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectEQ21
member.summary: Frequency bands : Band 1 : 22 Hz Band 2 : 32 Hz Band 3 : 44 Hz Band 4 : 63 Hz Band 5 : 90 Hz Band 6 : 125 Hz Band 7 : 175 Hz Band 8 : 250 Hz Band 9 : 350 Hz Band 10 : 500 Hz Band 11 : 700 Hz Band 12 : 1000 Hz Band 13 : 1400 Hz Band 14 : 2000 Hz Band 15 : 2800 Hz Band 16 : 4000 Hz Band 17 : 5600 Hz Band 18 : 8000 Hz Band 19 : 11000 Hz Band 20 : 16000 Hz Band 21 : 22000 Hz See also [AudioEffectEQ], [AudioEffectEQ6], [AudioEffectEQ10].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectEQ6
member.summary: Frequency bands : Band 1 : 32 Hz Band 2 : 100 Hz Band 3 : 320 Hz Band 4 : 1000 Hz Band 5 : 3200 Hz Band 6 : 10000 Hz See also [AudioEffectEQ], [AudioEffectEQ10], [AudioEffectEQ21].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectFilter
member.summary: Allows frequencies other than the [member cutoff_hz] to pass.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectFilter.CutoffHz
member.summary: Threshold frequency for the filter.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectFilter.Resonance
member.summary: Amount of boost in the overtones near the cutoff frequency.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectFilter.Gain
member.summary: Gain amount of the frequencies after the filter.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectHighPassFilter
member.summary: Cuts frequencies lower than the [member AudioEffectFilter.cutoff_hz] and allows higher frequencies to pass.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectLimiter
member.summary: A limiter is similar to a compressor, but it's less flexible and designed to disallow sound going over a given dB threshold. Adding one in the Master Bus is always recommended to reduce the effects of clipping. Soft clipping starts to reduce the peaks a little below the threshold level and progressively increases its effect as the input level increases such that the threshold is never exceeded.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectLimiter.CeilingDb
member.summary: The waveform's maximum allowed value. Value can range from -20 to -0.1. Default value: [code]-0.1dB[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectLimiter.ThresholdDb
member.summary: Threshold from which the limiter begins to be active. Value can range from -30 to 0. Default value: [code]0dB[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectLimiter.SoftClipDb
member.summary: Applies a gain to the limited waves. Value can range from 0 to 6. Default value: [code]2dB[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectLowPassFilter
member.summary: Cuts frequencies higher than the [member AudioEffectFilter.cutoff_hz] and allows lower frequencies to pass.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectNotchFilter
member.summary: Attenuates frequencies in a narrow band around the [member AudioEffectFilter.cutoff_hz] and cuts frequencies outside of this range.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectPanner
member.summary: Determines how much of an audio signal is sent to the left and right buses.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPanner.Pan
member.summary: Pan position. Value can range from -1 (fully left) to 1 (fully right).

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser
member.summary: Combines phase-shifted signals with the original signal. The movement of the phase-shifted signals is controlled using a Low Frequency Oscillator.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser.RangeMinHz
member.summary: Determines the minimum frequency affected by the LFO modulations. Value can range from 10 to 10000. Default value: [code]440hz[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser.RangeMaxHz
member.summary: Determines the maximum frequency affected by the LFO modulations. Value can range from 10 to 10000. Default value: [code]1600hz[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser.RateHz
member.summary: Adjusts the rate at which the effect sweeps up and down across the frequency range.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser.Feedback
member.summary: Output percent of modified sound. Value can range from 0.1 to 0.9. Default value: [code]0.7[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser.Depth
member.summary: Governs how high the filter frequencies sweep. Low value will primarily affect bass frequencies. High value can sweep high into the treble. Value can range from 0.1 to 4. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectPitchShift
member.summary: Allows modulation of pitch independently of tempo. All frequencies can be increased/decreased with minimal effect on transients.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPitchShift.PitchScale
member.summary: Pitch value. Can range from 0 (-1 octave) to 16 (+16 octaves).

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectReverb
member.summary: Simulates rooms of different sizes. Its parameters can be adjusted to simulate the sound of a specific room.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.PredelayMsec
member.summary: Time between the original signal and the early reflections of the reverb signal. Default value: [code]150ms[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.PredelayFeedback
member.summary: Output percent of predelay. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.RoomSize
member.summary: Dimensions of simulated room. Bigger means more echoes. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]0.8[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.Damping
member.summary: Defines how reflective the imaginary room's walls are. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.Spread
member.summary: Widens or narrows the stereo image of the reverb tail. 1 means fully widens. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.Hipass
member.summary: High-pass filter passes signals with a frequency higher than a certain cutoff frequency and attenuates signals with frequencies lower than the cutoff frequency. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]0[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.Dry
member.summary: Output percent of original sound. At 0, only modified sound is outputted. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.Wet
member.summary: Output percent of modified sound. At 0, only original sound is outputted. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]0.5[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.BackBufferCopy
member.summary: Node for back-buffering the currently displayed screen. The region defined in the BackBufferCopy node is bufferized with the content of the screen it covers, or the entire screen according to the copy mode set. Use [code]SCREEN_TEXTURE[/code] in the [code]texture()[/code] function to access the buffer.

member.name: F:Godot.BackBufferCopy.CopyModeEnum.Disabled
member.summary: Disables the buffering mode. This means the BackBufferCopy node will directly use the portion of screen it covers.

member.name: F:Godot.BackBufferCopy.CopyModeEnum.Rect
member.summary: BackBufferCopy buffers a rectangular region.

member.name: F:Godot.BackBufferCopy.CopyModeEnum.Viewport
member.summary: BackBufferCopy buffers the entire screen.

member.name: P:Godot.BackBufferCopy.CopyMode
member.summary: Buffer mode. See [code]COPY_MODE_*[/code] constants.

member.name: P:Godot.BackBufferCopy.Rect
member.summary: The area covered by the BackBufferCopy. Only used if [code]copy_mode[/code] is [code]COPY_MODE_RECT[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.BakedLightmap
member.summary: Baked lightmaps are an alternative workflow for adding indirect (or baked) lighting to a scene. Unlike the [GIProbe] approach, baked lightmaps work fine on low-end PCs and mobile devices as they consume almost no resources in run-time.

member.name: F:Godot.BakedLightmap.BakeQualityEnum.Low
member.summary: Lowest bake quality mode. Fastest to calculate.

member.name: F:Godot.BakedLightmap.BakeQualityEnum.Medium
member.summary: Default bake quality mode.

member.name: F:Godot.BakedLightmap.BakeQualityEnum.High
member.summary: Highest bake quality mode. Takes longer to calculate.

member.name: F:Godot.BakedLightmap.BakeModeEnum.ConeTrace
member.summary: Less precise but faster bake mode.

member.name: F:Godot.BakedLightmap.BakeModeEnum.RayTrace
member.summary: More precise bake mode but can take considerably longer to bake.

member.name: P:Godot.BakedLightmap.BakeCellSize
member.summary: Grid subdivision size for lightmapper calculation. Default value of [code]0.25[/code] will work for most cases. Increase for better lighting on small details or if your scene is very large.

member.name: P:Godot.BakedLightmap.BakeQuality
member.summary: Three quality modes are available. Higher quality requires more rendering time. See [enum BakeQuality].

member.name: P:Godot.BakedLightmap.BakeMode
member.summary: Lightmapping mode. See [enum BakeMode].

member.name: P:Godot.BakedLightmap.BakeHdr
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], lightmap can capture light values greater than [code]1.0[/code]. Turning this off will result in a smaller lightmap. Default value:[code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.BakedLightmap.BakeExtents
member.summary: Size of affected area.

member.name: P:Godot.BakedLightmap.CaptureCellSize
member.summary: Grid size used for real-time capture information on dynamic objects. Cannot be larger than [member bake_cell_size].

member.name: P:Godot.BakedLightmap.ImagePath
member.summary: Location where lightmaps will be saved.

member.name: P:Godot.BakedLightmap.LightData
member.summary: The calculated light data.

member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the button will add information about its shortcut in the tooltip.

member.summary: Binary mask to choose which mouse buttons this button will respond to. To allow both left-click and right-click, set this to 3, because it's BUTTON_MASK_LEFT | BUTTON_MASK_RIGHT.

member.summary: Focus access mode to use when switching between enabled/disabled (see [member Control.focus_mode] and [member disabled]).

member.name: P:Godot.BaseButton.Shortcut
member.summary: [ShortCut] associated to the button.

member.summary: [ButtonGroup] associated to the button.

member.summary: Return the visual state used to draw the button. This is useful mainly when implementing your own draw code by either overriding _draw() or connecting to "draw" signal. The visual state of the button is defined by the DRAW_* enum.

member.name: T:Godot.BitMap

member.summary: Creates a bitmap with the specified size, filled with false.

member.summary: Creates a bitmap that matches the given image dimensions, every element of the bitmap is set to false if the alpha value of the image at that position is equal to [code]threshold[/code] or less, and true in other case.

member.name: T:Godot.Camera
member.summary: Camera is a special node that displays what is visible from its current location. Cameras register themselves in the nearest [Viewport] node (when ascending the tree). Only one camera can be active per viewport. If no viewport is available ascending the tree, the Camera will register in the global viewport. In other words, a Camera just provides [i]3D[/i] display capabilities to a [Viewport], and, without one, a scene registered in that [Viewport] (or higher viewports) can't be displayed.

member.name: F:Godot.Camera.KeepAspectEnum.Width
member.summary: Preserves the horizontal aspect ratio.

member.name: F:Godot.Camera.KeepAspectEnum.Height
member.summary: Preserves the vertical aspect ratio.

member.name: F:Godot.Camera.ProjectionEnum.Perspective
member.summary: Perspective Projection (object's size on the screen becomes smaller when far away).

member.name: F:Godot.Camera.ProjectionEnum.Orthogonal
member.summary: Orthogonal Projection (objects remain the same size on the screen no matter how far away they are).

member.name: F:Godot.Camera.DopplerTrackingEnum.Disabled
member.summary: Disable Doppler effect simulation (default).

member.name: F:Godot.Camera.DopplerTrackingEnum.IdleStep
member.summary: Simulate Doppler effect by tracking positions of objects that are changed in [code]_process[/code]. Changes in the relative velocity of this Camera compared to those objects affect how Audio is perceived (changing the Audio's [code]pitch shift[/code]).

member.name: F:Godot.Camera.DopplerTrackingEnum.PhysicsStep
member.summary: Simulate Doppler effect by tracking positions of objects that are changed in [code]_physics_process[/code]. Changes in the relative velocity of this Camera compared to those objects affect how Audio is perceived (changing the Audio's [code]pitch shift[/code]).

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.KeepAspect
member.summary: The axis to lock during [member fov]/[member size] adjustments. Can be either [code]KEEP_WIDTH[/code] or [code]KEEP_HEIGHT[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.CullMask
member.summary: The culling mask that describes which 3D render layers are rendered by this camera.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.Environment
member.summary: The [Environment] to use for this Camera.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.HOffset
member.summary: The horizontal (X) offset of the Camera viewport.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.VOffset
member.summary: The vertical (Y) offset of the Camera viewport.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.DopplerTracking
member.summary: If not [code]DOPPLER_TRACKING_DISABLED[/code] this Camera will simulate the Doppler effect for objects changed in particular [code]_process[/code] methods. Default value: [code]DOPPLER_TRACKING_DISABLED[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.Projection
member.summary: The camera's projection mode. In [code]PROJECTION_PERSPECTIVE[/code] mode, objects' z-distance from the camera's local space scales their perceived size.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.Current
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the ancestor [Viewport] is currently using this Camera. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.Fov
member.summary: The camera's field of view angle (in degrees). Only applicable in perspective mode. Since [member keep_aspect] locks one axis, [code]fov[/code] sets the other axis' field of view angle.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.Size
member.summary: The camera's size measured as 1/2 the width or height. Only applicable in orthogonal mode. Since [member keep_aspect] locks on axis, [code]size[/code] sets the other axis' size length.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.Near
member.summary: The distance to the near culling boundary for this Camera relative to its local z-axis.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera.Far
member.summary: The distance to the far culling boundary for this Camera relative to its local z-axis.

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.ProjectRayNormal(Godot.Vector2)
member.summary: Returns a normal vector in worldspace, that is the result of projecting a point on the [Viewport] rectangle by the camera projection. This is useful for casting rays in the form of (origin, normal) for object intersection or picking.

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.ProjectLocalRayNormal(Godot.Vector2)
member.summary: Returns a normal vector from the screen point location directed along the camera. Orthogonal cameras are normalized. Perspective cameras account for perspective, screen width/height, etc.

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.ProjectRayOrigin(Godot.Vector2)
member.summary: Returns a 3D position in worldspace, that is the result of projecting a point on the [Viewport] rectangle by the camera projection. This is useful for casting rays in the form of (origin, normal) for object intersection or picking.

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.UnprojectPosition(Godot.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns the 2D coordinate in the [Viewport] rectangle that maps to the given 3D point in worldspace.

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.IsPositionBehind(Godot.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns [code]true[/code] if the given position is behind the Camera. Note that a position which returns [code]false[/code] may still be outside the Camera's field of view.

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.ProjectPosition(Godot.Vector2)
member.summary: Returns the 3D point in worldspace that maps to the given 2D coordinate in the [Viewport] rectangle.

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.SetPerspective(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the camera projection to perspective mode, by specifying a [i]FOV[/i] Y angle in degrees (FOV means Field of View), and the [i]near[/i] and [i]far[/i] clip planes in worldspace units.

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.SetOrthogonal(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the camera projection to orthogonal mode, by specifying a width and the [i]near[/i] and [i]far[/i] clip planes in worldspace units. (As a hint, 2D games often use this projection, with values specified in pixels)

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.MakeCurrent
member.summary: Makes this camera the current Camera for the [Viewport] (see class description). If the Camera Node is outside the scene tree, it will attempt to become current once it's added.

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.ClearCurrent(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If this is the current Camera, remove it from being current. If [code]enable_next[/code] is true, request to make the next Camera current, if any.

member.name: M:Godot.Camera.GetCameraTransform
member.summary: Gets the camera transform. Subclassed cameras (such as CharacterCamera) may provide different transforms than the [Node] transform.

member.name: T:Godot.Camera2D
member.summary: Camera node for 2D scenes. It forces the screen (current layer) to scroll following this node. This makes it easier (and faster) to program scrollable scenes than manually changing the position of [CanvasItem] based nodes. This node is intended to be a simple helper to get things going quickly and it may happen often that more functionality is desired to change how the camera works. To make your own custom camera node, simply inherit from [Node2D] and change the transform of the canvas by calling get_viewport().set_canvas_transform(m) in [Viewport].

member.name: F:Godot.Camera2D.AnchorModeEnum.FixedTopLeft
member.summary: The camera's position is fixed so that the top-left corner is always at the origin.

member.name: F:Godot.Camera2D.AnchorModeEnum.DragCenter
member.summary: The camera's position takes into account vertical/horizontal offsets and the screen size.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera2D.Offset
member.summary: The camera's offset, useful for looking around or camera shake animations.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera2D.AnchorMode
member.summary: The Camera2D's anchor point. See [code]ANCHOR_MODE_*[/code] constants.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera2D.Rotating
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the camera rotates with the target. Default value: [code]false[/code]

member.name: P:Godot.Camera2D.Current
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the camera is the active camera for the current scene. Only one camera can be current, so setting a different camera [code]current[/code] will disable this one.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera2D.Zoom
member.summary: The camera's zoom relative to the viewport. Values larger than [code]Vector2(1, 1)[/code] zoom out and smaller values zoom in. For an example, use [code]Vector2(0.5, 0.5)[/code] for a 2x zoom in, and [code]Vector2(4, 4)[/code] for a 4x zoom out.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera2D.CustomViewport
member.summary: The custom [Viewport] node attached to the [code]Camera2D[/code]. If null or not a [Viewport], uses the default viewport instead.

member.name: P:Godot.Camera2D.LimitLeft

member.name: T:Godot.CanvasItem
member.summary: Base class of anything 2D. Canvas items are laid out in a tree and children inherit and extend the transform of their parent. CanvasItem is extended by [Control], for anything GUI related, and by [Node2D] for anything 2D engine related. Any CanvasItem can draw. For this, the "update" function must be called, then NOTIFICATION_DRAW will be received on idle time to request redraw. Because of this, canvas items don't need to be redraw on every frame, improving the performance significantly. Several functions for drawing on the CanvasItem are provided (see draw_* functions). They can only be used inside the notification, signal or _draw() overrides function, though. Canvas items are draw in tree order. By default, children are on top of their parents so a root CanvasItem will be drawn behind everything (this can be changed per item though). Canvas items can also be hidden (hiding also their subtree). They provide many means for changing standard parameters such as opacity (for it and the subtree) and self opacity, blend mode. Ultimately, a transform notification can be requested, which will notify the node that its global position changed in case the parent tree changed.

member.name: T:Godot.CanvasLayer
member.summary: Canvas drawing layer. [CanvasItem] nodes that are direct or indirect children of a [code]CanvasLayer[/code] will be drawn in that layer. The layer is a numeric index that defines the draw order. The default 2D scene renders with index 0, so a [code]CanvasLayer[/code] with index -1 will be drawn below, and one with index 1 will be drawn above. This is very useful for HUDs (in layer 1+ or above), or backgrounds (in layer -1 or below).

member.name: P:Godot.CanvasLayer.Layer

member.name: T:Godot.CollisionObject
member.summary: CollisionObject is the base class for physics objects. It can hold any number of collision [Shape]s. Each shape must be assigned to a [i]shape owner[/i]. The CollisionObject can have any number of shape owners. Shape owners are not nodes and do not appear in the editor, but are accessible through code using the [code]shape_owner_*[/code] methods.

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionObject.InputRayPickable
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the [CollisionObject]'s shapes will respond to [RayCast]s. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionObject.InputCaptureOnDrag
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the [code]CollisionObject[/code] will continue to receive input events as the mouse is dragged across its shapes. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: M:Godot.CollisionObject._InputEvent(Godot.Object,Godot.InputEvent,Godot.Vector3,Godot.Vector3,System.Int32)
member.summary: Accepts unhandled [InputEvent]s. [code]click_position[/code] is the clicked location in world space and [code]click_normal[/code] is the normal vector extending from the clicked surface of the [Shape] at [code]shape_idx[/code]. Connect to the [code]input_event[/code] signal to easily pick up these events.

member.name: M:Godot.CollisionObject.GetRid

member.summary: Removes the given shape owner.

member.name: T:Godot.CollisionObject2D
member.summary: CollisionObject2D is the base class for 2D physics objects. It can hold any number of 2D collision [Shape2D]s. Each shape must be assigned to a [i]shape owner[/i]. The CollisionObject2D can have any number of shape owners. Shape owners are not nodes and do not appear in the editor, but are accessible through code using the [code]shape_owner_*[/code] methods.

member.name: T:Godot.CollisionPolygon
member.summary: Allows editing a collision polygon's vertices on a selected plane. Can also set a depth perpendicular to that plane. This class is only available in the editor. It will not appear in the scene tree at runtime. Creates a [Shape] for gameplay. Properties modified during gameplay will have no effect.

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionPolygon.Depth
member.summary: Length that the resulting collision extends in either direction perpendicular to its polygon.

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionPolygon.Disabled
member.summary: If true, no collision will be produced.

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionPolygon.Polygon
member.summary: Array of vertices which define the polygon. Note that the returned value is a copy of the original. Methods which mutate the size or properties of the return value will not impact the original polygon. To change properties of the polygon, assign it to a temporary variable and make changes before reassigning the [code]polygon[/code] member.

member.name: T:Godot.CollisionPolygon2D
member.summary: Provides a 2D collision polygon to a [CollisionObject2D] parent. Polygon can be drawn in the editor or specified by a list of vertices.

member.name: F:Godot.CollisionPolygon2D.BuildModeEnum.Solids
member.summary: Collisions will include the polygon and its contained area.

member.name: F:Godot.CollisionPolygon2D.BuildModeEnum.Segments
member.summary: Collisions will only include the polygon edges.

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionPolygon2D.BuildMode
member.summary: Collision build mode. Use one of the [code]BUILD_*[/code] constants. Default value: [code]BUILD_SOLIDS[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionPolygon2D.Polygon
member.summary: The polygon's list of vertices. The final point will be connected to the first. The returned value is a clone of the PoolVector2Array, not a reference.

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionPolygon2D.Disabled
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], no collisions will be detected.

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionPolygon2D.OneWayCollision
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], only edges that face up, relative to CollisionPolygon2D's rotation, will collide with other objects.

member.name: T:Godot.CollisionShape
member.summary: Editor facility for creating and editing collision shapes in 3D space. You can use this node to represent all sorts of collision shapes, for example, add this to an [Area] to give it a detection shape, or add it to a [PhysicsBody] to create a solid object. [b]IMPORTANT[/b]: this is an Editor-only helper to create shapes, use [method CollisionObject.shape_owner_get_shape] to get the actual shape.

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionShape.Shape
member.summary: The actual shape owned by this collision shape.

member.name: P:Godot.CollisionShape.Disabled
member.summary: A disabled collision shape has no effect in the world.

member.name: M:Godot.CollisionShape.MakeConvexFromBrothers

You can use this node to represent all sorts of collision shapes, for example, add this to an [Area2D] to give it a detection shape, or add it to a [PhysicsBody2D] to create a solid object. [b]IMPORTANT[/b]: this is an Editor-only helper to create shapes, use [method CollisionObject2D.shape_owner_get_shape] to get the actual shape.

member.name: P:Godot.ColorPicker.DeferredMode

member.name: T:Godot.ConcavePolygonShape
member.summary: Concave polygon shape resource, which can be set into a [PhysicsBody] or area. This shape is created by feeding a list of triangles.

member.name: M:Godot.ConcavePolygonShape.SetFaces(Godot.Vector3[])
member.summary: Set the faces (an array of triangles).

member.name: M:Godot.ConcavePolygonShape.GetFaces
member.summary: Return the faces (an array of triangles).

member.name: T:Godot.ConcavePolygonShape2D
member.summary: Concave polygon 2D shape resource for physics. It is made out of segments and is very optimal for complex polygonal concave collisions. It is really not advised to use for [RigidBody2D] nodes. A CollisionPolygon2D in convex decomposition mode (solids) or several convex objects are advised for that instead. Otherwise, a concave polygon 2D shape is better for static collisions. The main difference between a [ConvexPolygonShape2D] and a [code]ConcavePolygonShape2D[/code] is that a concave polygon assumes it is concave and uses a more complex method of collision detection, and a convex one forces itself to be convex in order to speed up collision detection.

member.name: P:Godot.ConcavePolygonShape2D.Segments
member.summary: The array of points that make up the [code]ConcavePolygonShape2D[/code]'s line segments.

member.name: T:Godot.ConeTwistJoint
member.summary: The joint can rotate the bodies across an axis defined by the local x-axes of the [Joint]. The twist axis is initiated as the x-axis of the [Joint]. Once the Bodies swing, the twist axis is calculated as the middle of the x-axes of the Joint in the local space of the two Bodies.

member.name: F:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.Param.SwingSpan
member.summary: Swing is rotation from side to side, around the axis perpendicular to the twist axis. The swing span defines, how much rotation will not get corrected allong the swing axis. Could be defined as looseness in the [code]ConeTwistJoint[/code]. If below 0.05, this behaviour is locked. Default value: [code]PI/4[/code].

member.name: F:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.Param.TwistSpan
member.summary: Twist is the rotation around the twist axis, this value defined how far the joint can twist. Twist is locked if below 0.05.

member.name: F:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.Param.Bias
member.summary: The speed with which the swing or twist will take place. The higher, the faster.

member.name: F:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.Param.Softness
member.summary: The ease with which the joint starts to twist. If it's too low, it takes more force to start twisting the joint.

member.name: F:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.Param.Relaxation
member.summary: Defines, how fast the swing- and twist-speed-difference on both sides gets synced.

member.name: F:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.Param.Max
member.summary: End flag of PARAM_* constants, used internally.

member.name: P:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.SwingSpan
member.summary: Swing is rotation from side to side, around the axis perpendicular to the twist axis. The swing span defines, how much rotation will not get corrected allong the swing axis. Could be defined as looseness in the [code]ConeTwistJoint[/code]. If below 0.05, this behaviour is locked. Default value: [code]PI/4[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.TwistSpan
member.summary: Twist is the rotation around the twist axis, this value defined how far the joint can twist. Twist is locked if below 0.05.

member.name: P:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.Bias
member.summary: The speed with which the swing or twist will take place. The higher, the faster.

member.name: P:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.Softness
member.summary: The ease with which the joint starts to twist. If it's too low, it takes more force to start twisting the joint.

member.name: P:Godot.ConeTwistJoint.Relaxation
member.summary: Defines, how fast the swing- and twist-speed-difference on both sides gets synced.

member.name: T:Godot.ConfigFile
member.summary: This helper class can be used to store [Variant] values on the filesystem using INI-style formatting. The stored values are identified by a section and a key: [codeblock] [section] some_key=42 string_example="Hello World!" a_vector=Vector3( 1, 0, 2 ) [/codeblock] The stored data can be saved to or parsed from a file, though ConfigFile objects can also be used directly without accessing the filesystem. The following example shows how to parse an INI-style file from the system, read its contents and store new values in it: [codeblock] var config = ConfigFile.new() var err = config.load("user://settings.cfg") if err == OK: # if not, something went wrong with the file loading # Look for the display/width pair, and default to 1024 if missing var screen_width = config.get_value("display", "width", 1024) # Store a variable if and only if it hasn't been defined yet if not config.has_section_key("audio", "mute"): config.set_value("audio", "mute", false) # Save the changes by overwriting the previous file config.save("user://settings.cfg") [/codeblock] Keep in mind that section and property names can't contain spaces. Anything after a space will be ignored on save and on load.

member.name: M:Godot.ConfigFile.SetValue(System.String,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Assigns a value to the specified key of the specified section. If the section and/or the key do not exist, they are created. Passing a [code]null[/code] value deletes the specified key if it exists, and deletes the section if it ends up empty once the key has been removed.

member.name: M:Godot.ConfigFile.GetValue(System.String,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the current value for the specified section and key. If the section and/or the key do not exist, the method returns the value of the optional [code]default[/code] argument, or [code]null[/code] if it is omitted.

member.name: M:Godot.ConfigFile.HasSection(System.String)
member.summary: Returns [code]true[/code] if the specified section exists.

member.name: M:Godot.ConfigFile.HasSectionKey(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns [code]true[/code] if the specified section-key pair exists.

member.name: M:Godot.ConfigFile.GetSections
member.summary: Returns an array of all defined section identifiers.

member.name: M:Godot.ConfigFile.GetSectionKeys(System.String)
member.summary: Returns an array of all defined key identifiers in the specified section.

member.name: M:Godot.ConfigFile.EraseSection(System.String)
member.summary: Deletes the specified section along with all the key-value pairs inside.

member.name: M:Godot.ConfigFile.Load(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the config file specified as a parameter. The file's contents are parsed and loaded in the ConfigFile object which the method was called on. Returns one of the [code]OK[/code], [code]FAILED[/code] or [code]ERR_*[/code] constants listed in [@GlobalScope]. If the load was successful, the return value is [code]OK[/code].

member.name: M:Godot.ConfigFile.Save(System.String)
member.summary: Saves the contents of the ConfigFile object to the file specified as a parameter. The output file uses an INI-style structure. Returns one of the [code]OK[/code], [code]FAILED[/code] or [code]ERR_*[/code] constants listed in [@GlobalScope]. If the load was successful, the return value is [code]OK[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.Container
