member.name: T:Godot.VBoxContainer
member.summary: Vertical box container. See [BoxContainer].

member.name: T:Godot.VehicleBody
member.summary: This nodes implements all the physics logic needed to simulate a car. It is based on the raycast vehicle system commonly found in physics engines. You will need to add a [CollisionShape] for the main body of your vehicle and add [VehicleWheel] nodes for the wheels. You should also add a [MeshInstance] to this node for the 3D model of your car but this model should not include meshes for the wheels. You should control the vehicle by using the [member brake], [member engine_force], and [member steering] properties and not change the position or orientation of this node directly. Note that the origin point of your VehicleBody will determine the center of gravity of your vehicle so it is better to keep this low and move the [CollisionShape] and [MeshInstance] upwards.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleBody.EngineForce
member.summary: Accelerates the vehicle by applying an engine force. The vehicle is only speed up if the wheels that have [member VehicleWheel.use_as_traction] set to true and are in contact with a surface. The [member RigidBody.mass] of the vehicle has an effect on the acceleration of the vehicle. For a vehicle with a mass set to 1000, try a value in the 25 - 50 range for acceleration. Note that the simulation does not take the effect of gears into account, you will need to add logic for this if you wish to simulate gears. A negative value will result in the vehicle reversing.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleBody.Brake
member.summary: Slows down the vehicle by applying a braking force. The vehicle is only slowed down if the wheels are in contact with a surface. The force you need to apply to adequately slow down your vehicle depends on the [member RigidBody.mass] of the vehicle. For a vehicle with a mass set to 1000, try a value in the 25 - 30 range for hard braking.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleBody.Steering
member.summary: The steering angle for the vehicle. Setting this to a non-zero value will result in the vehicle turning when it's moving. Wheels that have [member VehicleWheel.use_as_steering] set to true will automatically be rotated.

member.name: T:Godot.VehicleWheel
member.summary: This node needs to be used as a child node of [VehicleBody] and simulates the behaviour of one of its wheels. This node also acts as a collider to detect if the wheel is touching a surface.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.UseAsTraction
member.summary: If true this wheel transfers engine force to the ground to propel the vehicle forward.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.UseAsSteering
member.summary: If true this wheel will be turned when the car steers.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.WheelRollInfluence
member.summary: This value effects the roll of your vehicle. If set to 0.0 for all wheels your vehicle will be prone to rolling over while a value of 1.0 will resist body roll.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.WheelRadius
member.summary: The radius of the wheel in meters.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.WheelRestLength
member.summary: This is the distance in meters the wheel is lowered from its origin point. Don't set this to 0.0 and move the wheel into position, instead move the origin point of your wheel (the gizmo in Godot) to the position the wheel will take when bottoming out, then use the rest length to move the wheel down to the position it should be in when the car is in rest.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.WheelFrictionSlip
member.summary: This determines how much grip this wheel has. It is combined with the friction setting of the surface the wheel is in contact with. 0.0 means no grip, 1.0 is normal grip. For a drift car setup, try setting the grip of the rear wheels slightly lower than the front wheels, or use a lower value to simulate tire wear. It's best to set this to 1.0 when starting out.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.SuspensionTravel
member.summary: This is the distance the suspension can travel. As Godot measures are in meters keep this setting relatively low. Try a value between 0.1 and 0.3 depending on the type of car .

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.SuspensionStiffness
member.summary: This value defines the stiffness of the suspension. Use a value lower than 50 for an off-road car, a value between 50 and 100 for a race car and try something around 200 for something like a Formula 1 car.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.SuspensionMaxForce
member.summary: The maximum force the spring can resist. This value should be higher than a quarter of the [member RigidBody.mass] of the [VehicleBody] or the spring will not carry the weight of the vehicle. Good results are often obtained by a value that is about 3x to 4x this number.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.DampingCompression
member.summary: The damping applied to the spring when the spring is being compressed. This value should be between 0.0 (no damping) and 1.0. A value of 0.0 means the car will keep bouncing as the spring keeps its energy. A good value for this is around 0.3 for a normal car, 0.5 for a race car.

member.name: P:Godot.VehicleWheel.DampingRelaxation
member.summary: The damping applied to the spring when relaxing. This value should be between 0.0 (no damping) and 1.0. This value should always be slightly higher than the [member damping_compression] property. For a [member damping_compression] value of 0.3, try a relaxation value of 0.5

member.name: M:Godot.VehicleWheel.IsInContact
member.summary: Returns true if this wheel is in contact with a surface.

member.name: M:Godot.VehicleWheel.GetSkidinfo
member.summary: Returns a value between 0.0 and 1.0 that indicates whether this wheel is skidding. 0.0 is not skidding, 1.0 means the wheel has lost grip.

member.name: T:Godot.Viewport
member.summary: A Viewport creates a different view into the screen, or a sub-view inside another viewport. Children 2D Nodes will display on it, and children Camera 3D nodes will render on it too. Optionally, a viewport can have its own 2D or 3D world, so they don't share what they draw with other viewports. If a viewport is a child of a [ViewportContainer], it will automatically take up its size, otherwise it must be set manually. Viewports can also choose to be audio listeners, so they generate positional audio depending on a 2D or 3D camera child of it. Also, viewports can be assigned to different screens in case the devices have multiple screens. Finally, viewports can also behave as render targets, in which case they will not be visible unless the associated texture is used to draw.

member.name: F:Godot.Viewport.ClearMode.Always
member.summary: Always clear the render target before drawing.

member.name: F:Godot.Viewport.ClearMode.Never
member.summary: Never clear the render target.

member.name: F:Godot.Viewport.ClearMode.OnlyNextFrame
member.summary: Clear the render target next frame, then switch to [code]CLEAR_MODE_NEVER[/code].

member.name: F:Godot.Viewport.RenderInfo.ObjectsInFrame
member.summary: Amount of objects in frame.

member.summary: Multisample anti-aliasing mode disabled. This is the default value.

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.Arvr
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the viewport will be used in AR/VR process. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.Size
member.summary: The width and height of viewport.

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.OwnWorld
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the viewport will use [World] defined in [code]world[/code] property. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.World
member.summary: The custom [World] which can be used as 3D environment source.

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.World2d
member.summary: The custom [World2D] which can be used as 2D environment source.

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.TransparentBg
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the viewport should render its background as transparent. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.Msaa
member.summary: The multisample anti-aliasing mode. Default value: [code]MSAA_DISABLED[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.Hdr
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the viewport rendering will receive benefits from High Dynamic Range algorithm. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.Disable3d
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the viewport will disable 3D rendering. For actual disabling use [code]usage[/code]. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.Keep3dLinear
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the result after 3D rendering will not have a linear to sRGB color conversion applied. This is important when the viewport is used as a render target where the result is used as a texture on a 3D object rendered in another viewport. It is also important if the viewport is used to create data that is not color based (noise, heightmaps, pickmaps, etc.). Do not enable this when the viewport is used as a texture on a 2D object or if the viewport is your final output.

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.Usage
member.summary: The rendering mode of viewport. Default value: [code]USAGE_3D[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.DebugDraw
member.summary: The overlay mode for test rendered geometry in debug purposes. Default value: [code]DEBUG_DRAW_DISABLED[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.RenderTargetVFlip
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the result of rendering will be flipped vertically. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.RenderTargetClearMode
member.summary: The clear mode when viewport used as a render target. Default value: [code]CLEAR_MODE_ALWAYS[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.RenderTargetUpdateMode
member.summary: The update mode when viewport used as a render target. Default value: [code]UPDATE_WHEN_VISIBLE[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.AudioListenerEnable2d
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the viewport will process 2D audio streams. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.AudioListenerEnable3d
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the viewport will process 3D audio streams. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.PhysicsObjectPicking
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the objects rendered by viewport become subjects of mouse picking process. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.GuiDisableInput
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the viewport will not receive input event. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.GuiSnapControlsToPixels
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the GUI controls on the viewport will lay pixel perfectly. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.summary: The resolution of shadow atlas. Both width and height is equal to one value.

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.ShadowAtlasQuad3

member.name: P:Godot.Viewport.CanvasTransform

member.name: M:Godot.Viewport.SetSizeOverride(System.Boolean,System.Nullable{Godot.Vector2},System.Nullable{Godot.Vector2})
member.summary: Sets the size override of the viewport. If the [code]enable[/code] parameter is [code]true[/code] the override is used, otherwise it uses the default size. If the size parameter is [code](-1, -1)[/code], it won't update the size. <param name="size">If the param is null, then the default value is new Vector2(-1, -1)</param> <param name="margin">If the param is null, then the default value is new Vector2(0, 0)</param>

member.summary: Returns the size override set with [method set_size_override].

member.name: M:Godot.Viewport.SetSizeOverrideStretch(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], the size override affects stretch as well.

member.name: M:Godot.Viewport.IsSizeOverrideStretchEnabled
member.summary: Returns [code]true[/code] if the size stretch override is enabled. See [method set_size_override_stretch].

member.summary: Returns information about the viewport from the rendering pipeline.

member.name: M:Godot.Viewport.GetTexture
member.summary: Returns the viewport's texture. Note that due to the way OpenGL works, the resulting [ViewportTexture] is flipped vertically. You can use [method Image.flip_y] on the result of [method Texture.get_data] to flip it back, for example: [codeblock] var img = get_viewport().get_texture().get_data() img.flip_y() [/codeblock]

member.name: T:Godot.ViewportTexture
member.summary: Displays the content of a [Viewport] node as a dynamic [Texture]. This can be used to mix controls, 2D, and 3D elements in the same scene. To create a ViewportTexture in code, use the [method Viewport.get_texture] method on the target viewport.

member.name: P:Godot.ViewportTexture.ViewportPath
member.summary: The path to the [Viewport] node to display. This is relative to the scene root, not to the node which uses the texture.

member.name: T:Godot.VisualScript
member.summary: A script implemented in the Visual Script programming environment. The script extends the functionality of all objects that instance it. [method Object.set_script] extends an existing object, if that object's class matches one of the script's base classes. You are most likely to use this class via the Visual Script editor or when writing plugins for it.

member.name: T:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc
member.summary: A built-in function used inside a [VisualScript]. It is usually a math function or an utility function. See also [@GDScript], for the same functions in the GDScript language.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathSin
member.summary: Return the sine of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathCos
member.summary: Return the cosine of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathTan
member.summary: Return the tangent of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathSinh
member.summary: Return the hyperbolic sine of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathCosh
member.summary: Return the hyperbolic cosine of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathTanh
member.summary: Return the hyperbolic tangent of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathAsin
member.summary: Return the arc sine of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathAcos
member.summary: Return the arc cosine of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathAtan
member.summary: Return the arc tangent of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathAtan2
member.summary: Return the arc tangent of the input, using the signs of both parameters to determine the exact angle.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathSqrt
member.summary: Return the square root of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathFmod
member.summary: Return the remainder of one input divided by the other, using floating-point numbers.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathFposmod
member.summary: Return the positive remainder of one input divided by the other, using floating-point numbers.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathFloor
member.summary: Return the input rounded down.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathCeil
member.summary: Return the input rounded up.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathRound
member.summary: Return the input rounded to the nearest integer.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathAbs
member.summary: Return the absolute value of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathSign
member.summary: Return the sign of the input, turning it into 1, -1, or 0. Useful to determine if the input is positive or negative.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathPow
member.summary: Return the input raised to a given power.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathLog
member.summary: Return the natural logarithm of the input. Note that this is not the typical base-10 logarithm function calculators use.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathExp
member.summary: Return the mathematical constant [b]e[/b] raised to the specified power of the input. [b]e[/b] has an approximate value of 2.71828.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathIsnan
member.summary: Return whether the input is NaN (Not a Number) or not. NaN is usually produced by dividing 0 by 0, though other ways exist.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathIsinf
member.summary: Return whether the input is an infinite floating-point number or not. Infinity is usually produced by dividing a number by 0, though other ways exist.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathEase
member.summary: Easing function, based on exponent. 0 is constant, 1 is linear, 0 to 1 is ease-in, 1+ is ease out. Negative values are in-out/out in.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathDecimals
member.summary: Return the number of digit places after the decimal that the first non-zero digit occurs.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathStepify
member.summary: Return the input snapped to a given step.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathLerp
member.summary: Return a number linearly interpolated between the first two inputs, based on the third input. Uses the formula [code]a + (a - b) * t[/code].

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathDectime
member.summary: Return the result of 'value' decreased by 'step' * 'amount'.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.BuiltinFunc.MathRandomize

member.name: T:Godot.VisualScriptCondition
member.summary: A Visual Script node that checks a [bool] input port. If [code]true[/code], it will exit via the "true" sequence port. If [code]false[/code], it will exit via the "false" sequence port. After exiting either, it exits via the "done" port. Sequence ports may be left disconnected. [b]Input Ports:[/b] - Sequence: [code]if (cond) is[/code] - Data (boolean): [code]cond[/code] [b]Output Ports:[/b] - Sequence: [code]true[/code] - Sequence: [code]false[/code] - Sequence: [code]done[/code]

member.name: T:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode
member.summary: A custom Visual Script node which can be scripted in powerful ways.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.StepPushStackBit
member.summary: Hint used by [method _step] to tell that control should return to it when there is no other node left to execute. This is used by [VisualScriptCondition] to redirect the sequence to the "Done" port after the true/false branch has finished execution.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.StepGoBackBit
member.summary: Hint used by [method _step] to tell that control should return back, either hitting a previous STEP_PUSH_STACK_BIT or exiting the function.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.StepExitFunctionBit
member.summary: Hint used by [method _step] to tell that control should stop and exit the function.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.StepYieldBit
member.summary: Hint used by [method _step] to tell that the function should be yielded. Using this requires you to have at least one working memory slot, which is used for the [VisualScriptFunctionState].

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.StartMode.BeginSequence
member.summary: The start mode used the first time when [method _step] is called.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.StartMode.ContinueSequence
member.summary: The start mode used when [method _step] is called after coming back from a STEP_PUSH_STACK_BIT.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.StartMode.ResumeYield
member.summary: The start mode used when [method _step] is called after resuming from STEP_YIELD_BIT.

member.summary: Return the custom node's text, which is shown right next to the input [b]sequence[/b] port (if there is none, on the place that is usually taken by it).

member.summary: Return the size of the custom node's working memory. See [method _step] for more details.

member.name: M:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode._HasInputSequencePort
member.summary: Return whether the custom node has an input [b]sequence[/b] port.

member.name: M:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode._Step(Godot.Collections.Array,Godot.Collections.Array,System.Int32,Godot.Collections.Array)
member.summary: Execute the custom node's logic, returning the index of the output sequence port to use or a [String] when there is an error. The [code]inputs[/code] array contains the values of the input ports. [code]outputs[/code] is an array whose indices should be set to the respective outputs. The [code]start_mode[/code] is usually [code]START_MODE_BEGIN_SEQUENCE[/code], unless you have used the STEP_* constants. [code]working_mem[/code] is an array which can be used to persist information between runs of the custom node. When returning, you can mask the returned value with one of the STEP_* constants.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualServer.TextureFlags.AnisotropicFilter
member.summary: Anisotropic mipmap filtering. Generates smaller versions of the same texture with different aspect ratios. More effective on planes often shown going to the horrizon as those textures (Walls or Ground for example) get squashed in the viewport to different aspect ratios and regular mipmaps keep the aspect ratio so they don't optimize storage that well in those cases.

member.name: T:Godot.WeakRef
member.summary: A weakref can hold a [Reference], without contributing to the reference counter. A weakref can be created from an [Object] using [method @GDScript.weakref]. If this object is not a reference, weakref still works, however, it does not have any effect on the object. Weakrefs are useful in cases where multiple classes have variables that refer to each other. Without weakrefs, using these classes could lead to memory leaks, since both references keep each other from being released. Making part of the variables a weakref can prevent this cyclic dependency, and allows the references to be released.

member.name: M:Godot.WeakRef.GetRef
member.summary: Returns the [Object] this weakref is referring to.

member.name: T:Godot.WebSocketClient
member.summary: This class implements a WebSocket client compatible with any RFC 6455 complaint WebSocket server. This client can be optionally used as a network peer for the [MultiplayerAPI]. After starting the client ([method connect_to_url]), you will need to [method NetworkedMultiplayerPeer.poll] it at regular intervals (e.g. inside [method Node._process]). You will received appropriate signals when connecting, disconnecting, or when new data is available.

member.name: P:Godot.WebSocketClient.VerifySsl
member.summary: Enable or disable SSL certificate verification. Note: You must specify the certificates to be used in the project settings for it to work when exported.

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketClient.ConnectToUrl(System.String,System.String[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Connect to the given URL requesting one of the given [code]protocols[/code] as sub-protocol. If [code]true[/code] is passed as [code]gd_mp_api[/code], the client will behave like a network peer for the [MultiplayerAPI], connections to non Godot servers will not work, and [signal data_received] will not be emitted. If [code]false[/code] is passed instead (default), you must call [PacketPeer] functions ([code]put_packet[/code], [code]get_packet[/code], etc.) on the [WebSocketPeer] returned via [code]get_peer(1)[/code] and not on this object directly (e.g. [code]get_peer(1).put_packet(data)[/code]). <param name="protocols">If the param is null, then the default value is new string[] {}</param>

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketClient.DisconnectFromHost(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Disconnect this client from the connected host. See [method WebSocketPeer.close] for more info.

member.name: T:Godot.WebSocketMultiplayerPeer
member.summary: Base class for WebSocket server and client, allowing them to be used as network peer for the [MultiplayerAPI].

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketMultiplayerPeer.GetPeer(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the [WebSocketPeer] associated to the given [code]peer_id[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.WebSocketPeer
member.summary: This class represent a specific WebSocket connection, you can do lower level operations with it. You can choose to write to the socket in binary or text mode, and you can recognize the mode used for writing by the other peer.

member.name: F:Godot.WebSocketPeer.WriteMode.Text
member.summary: Specify that WebSockets messages should be transferred as text payload (only valid UTF-8 is allowed).

member.name: F:Godot.WebSocketPeer.WriteMode.Binary
member.summary: Specify that WebSockets messages should be transferred as binary payload (any byte combination is allowed).

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketPeer.GetWriteMode
member.summary: Get the current selected write mode. See [enum WriteMode].

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketPeer.SetWriteMode(Godot.WebSocketPeer.WriteMode)
member.summary: Sets the socket to use the given [enum WriteMode].

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketPeer.IsConnectedToHost
member.summary: Returns [code]true[/code] if this peer is currently connected.

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketPeer.WasStringPacket
member.summary: Returns [code]true[/code] if the last received packet was sent as a text payload. See [enum WriteMode]

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketPeer.Close(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Close this WebSocket connection. [code]code[/code] is the status code for the closure (see RFC6455 section 7.4 for a list of valid status codes). [code]reason[/code] is the human readable reason for closing the connection (can be any UTF8 string, must be less than 123 bytes). Note: To achieve a clean close, you will need to keep polling until either [signal WebSocketClient.connection_closed] or [signal WebSocketServer.client_disconnected] is received. Note: HTML5 export might not support all status codes. Please refer to browsers-specific documentation for more details.

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketPeer.GetConnectedHost
member.summary: Returns the IP Address of the connected peer. (Not available in HTML5 export)

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketPeer.GetConnectedPort
member.summary: Returns the remote port of the connected peer. (Not available in HTML5 export)

member.name: T:Godot.WebSocketServer
member.summary: This class implements a WebSocket server that can also support the high level multiplayer API. After starting the server ([method listen]), you will need to [method NetworkedMultiplayerPeer.poll] it at regular intervals (e.g. inside [method Node._process]). When clients connect, disconnect, or send data, you will receive the appropriate signal. Note: This class will not work in HTML5 exports due to browser restrictions.

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketServer.IsListening
member.summary: Returns [code]true[/code] if the server is actively listening on a port.

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketServer.Listen(System.Int32,System.String[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Start listening on the given port. You can specify the desired subprotocols via the "protocols" array. If the list empty (default), "binary" will be used. If [code]true[/code] is passed as [code]gd_mp_api[/code], the server will behave like a network peer for the [MultiplayerAPI], connections from non Godot clients will not work, and [signal data_received] will not be emitted. If [code]false[/code] is passed instead (default), you must call [PacketPeer] functions ([code]put_packet[/code], [code]get_packet[/code], etc.), on the [WebSocketPeer] returned via [code]get_peer(ID)[/code] to communicate with the peer with given [code]ID[/code] (e.g. [code]get_peer(ID).get_available_packet_count[/code]). <param name="protocols">If the param is null, then the default value is new string[] {}</param>

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketServer.Stop
member.summary: Stop the server and clear its state.

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketServer.HasPeer(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns [code]true[/code] if a peer with the given ID is connected.

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketServer.GetPeerAddress(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the IP address of the given peer.

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketServer.GetPeerPort(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the remote port of the given peer.

member.name: M:Godot.WebSocketServer.DisconnectPeer(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Disconnects the peer identified by [code]id[/code] from the server. See [method WebSocketPeer.close] for more info.

member.summary: The [RID] of this world's canvas resource. Used by the [VisualServer] for 2D drawing.

member.name: T:Godot.WorldEnvironment
member.summary: The [code]WorldEnvironment[/code] node is used to configure the default [Environment] for the scene. The parameters defined in the [code]WorldEnvironment[/code] can be overridden by an [Environment] node set on the current [Camera]. Additionally, only one [code]WorldEnvironment[/code] may be instanced in a given scene at a time. The [code]WorldEnvironment[/code] allows the user to specify default lighting parameters (e.g. ambient lighting), various post-processing effects (e.g. SSAO, DOF, Tonemapping), and how to draw the background (e.g. solid color, skybox). Usually, these are added in order to improve the realism/color balance of the scene.

member.name: P:Godot.WorldEnvironment.Environment
member.summary: The [Environment] resource used by this [code]WorldEnvironment[/code], defining the default properties.

member.name: T:Godot.YSort
member.summary: Sort all child nodes based on their Y positions. The child node must inherit from [CanvasItem] for it to be sorted. Nodes that have a higher Y position will be drawn later, so they will appear on top of nodes that have a lower Y position.

member.name: P:Godot.YSort.SortEnabled
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], child nodes are sorted, otherwise sorting is disabled. Default: [code]true[/code].
